parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting most or all fishing in Marine Protected Areas has shown varied effects on fish populations.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Caribbean Sea noted lower total fish species richness in areas closed to fishing compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 3]: A global review reported that one of 11 studies found higher fish species richness inside reserves.
[Statement 4]: A global review indicated that 10 of 11 studies found higher fish abundance within marine reserves.
[Statement 5]: A study in the Pacific Ocean observed similar abundance levels of certain rockfish and lingcod between 'no-take' reserves and fished areas.
[Statement 6]: A study in the Caribbean Sea found similar total fish biomass in a restricted area compared to an unprotected area.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Caribbean Sea found lower total fish density in a restricted area compared to an unprotected one.
[Statement 8]: One study observed increased survival for cod.
[Statement 9]: Another study observed higher survival for blackspot snapper.
[Statement 10]: Some studies found that fish were of a larger average size within marine parks with fishing restrictions.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found that fish reached older ages within marine parks with fishing restrictions.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the observed effects on fish abundance and diversity from prohibiting most or all fishing within Marine Protected Areas?
_gemini-2-5-pro__Besides changing hook type in longline fisheries, what other gear modifications can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Increasing the lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate was found to reduce catches of unwanted sharks and/or rays.
[Statement 2]: Using nylon instead of wire for hook attachments was found to reduce catches of unwanted sharks and/or rays.
[Statement 3]: One review found that using nylon hook attachments instead of wire increased the survival of unwanted sharks and rays for two of three species.
[Statement 4]: Another study found that using nylon hook attachments instead of wire reduced the survival of unwanted sharks and rays.
[Statement 5]: Attaching an electropositive deterrent to fishing gear has been examined.
[Statement 6]: Studies found that electropositive deterrents could reduce feeding attempts by some shark species.
[Statement 7]: Studies found that electropositive deterrents could reduce bait consumption by some shark species.
[Statement 8]: The results on the reduction of unwanted catch from using electropositive deterrents are mixed.
[Statement 9]: Two of four studies found that gear with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted sharks and rays.
[Statement 10]: Two other studies found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to gear without deterrents.
[Statement 11]: A global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to gear without deterrents.

[Statement 1]: Studies in the North Sea have found various gear modifications to be effective in reducing the unwanted catch of cod and haddock.
[Statement 2]: A separator trawl with a larger mesh size in the lower codend allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape.
[Statement 3]: Topless trawls have been found to reduce the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod.
[Statement 4]: One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock and larger Atlantic cod.
[Statement 5]: One study found that topless trawls did not reduce unwanted catches of smaller haddock.
[Statement 6]: Fitting size-sorting escape grids to trawl nets has been shown to reduce the catch of unwanted sizes of cod and haddock.
[Statement 7]: One study found that size-sorting escape grids improved the size-selection of haddock, but not cod, compared to standard nets.
[Statement 8]: Another study found that trawl nets with an escape grid did not improve the size-selection of cod and haddock when compared to nets with square mesh escape windows.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the English Channel found that the size-selectivity of whiting was increased in bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels or cylinders in combination with one or two size-sorting grids of different types, compared to standard nets.
[Statement 2]: Four of five replicated studies found that bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids of various types reduced the unwanted catch of fish, sharks, stingrays, rays, and total discarded catch, compared to standard unmodified trawl nets.
[Statement 3]: The escape of non-target fish from the combined use of a square mesh panel and a grid depended on the position of the panel in the net.
[Statement 4]: Three of four replicated studies found that trawl nets fitted with both a size-sorting escape grid and a large supported escape opening reduced the catches of unwanted fish, sharks, and rays, compared to standard trawl nets.
[Statement 5]: Trawl nets fitted with both a size-sorting escape grid and a large supported escape opening did not reduce the catches of sawfish in three of four replicated studies.
[Statement 6]: One study found that trawl nets with an escape grid and opening caught similar amounts of unwanted sharks as trawl nets without these modifications.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings compare in their effectiveness at improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the Coral Sea found that in areas closed to non-towed fishing gears, overall shark abundance was higher when sampled with longlines but not gillnets, compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Indian Ocean found that prohibiting offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area zone resulted in higher abundances of four over-exploited fish species compared to zones where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted.
[Statement 3]: One study in the Greenland Sea, North Pacific Ocean and the North Atlantic Ocean found that an area where fishing gears targeting bottom-dwelling species had been prohibited for 15 years had higher numbers of cod than openly fished areas.
[Statement 4]: A study found that fish densities in areas closed to mobile and static bottom fish gears for at least 11 years varied between fish species and groups, and also with depth and temperature.
[Statement 5]: A study found that prohibiting mobile and static bottom fish gears in protected areas for 2–7 years had no effect on fish densities compared to non-protected areas.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the comparative effects on fish abundance of prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A site comparison study in marine protected areas with zonation systems found a higher number of fish species in no-fishing/no access zones compared to partially fished zones.
[Statement 2]: One study found higher fish species richness inside reserves with restricted fishing activity compared to non-protected areas.
[Statement 3]: Zones with complete fishing bans, such as no-take or no-entry zones, had higher fish density when compared to zones where fishing was permitted or to unprotected areas.
[Statement 4]: Zones with complete fishing bans, such as no-take or no-entry zones, had higher fish biomass when compared to zones where fishing was permitted or to unprotected areas.
[Statement 5]: Zones with complete fishing bans, such as no-take or no-entry zones, had higher fish abundance when compared to zones where fishing was permitted or to unprotected areas.
[Statement 6]: A global review found that 10 of 11 studies showed higher fish abundance inside areas with restricted fishing compared to areas without fishing restrictions.
[Statement 7]: Fish had larger average lengths in zones where fishing was prohibited or nearly all prohibited, compared to zones with fewer fishing restrictions.
[Statement 8]: Fish had larger average sizes in zones where fishing was prohibited or nearly all prohibited, compared to zones with fewer fishing restrictions.
[Statement 9]: A study noted different age and sex structures for the fish species steentjies between a no-fishing zone, a fished multipurpose zone, and an unprotected fished site.
[Statement 10]: Blackspot snapper were found to be larger inside a marine park with unspecified fishing restrictions compared to more intensely fished areas outside the park.
[Statement 11]: Blackspot snapper were found to be older inside a marine park with unspecified fishing restrictions compared to more intensely fished areas outside the park.
[Statement 12]: A global review reported that five of 11 studies found fish were larger inside reserves with restricted fishing.
[Statement 13]: The survival rate for blackspot snapper was higher within a marine park with unspecified fishing restrictions compared to more heavily fished areas outside the park.
[Statement 14]: Tagged reef fish were mostly recaptured within the zones where fishing was prohibited.
[Statement 15]: The recapture of tagged fish within prohibited fishing zones indicates that the restrictions provided the fish with protection from fishing.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the outcomes for fish populations when marine protected areas are managed with zonation systems that permit some fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies in the North Atlantic Ocean have shown that prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear can lead to higher numbers of larger and older cod.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear in the North Atlantic Ocean can lead to better growth in cod.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear in the North Atlantic Ocean can lead to higher total fish biomass.
[Statement 4]: Other studies in the North Atlantic have found that closing an area to bottom trawling did not increase the survival or recruitment of young haddock.
[Statement 5]: In the Mediterranean Sea, the prohibition of towed bottom gear has been found to increase the biomass of red mullet.
[Statement 6]: In the Mediterranean Sea, the prohibition of towed bottom gear has been found to increase the size of red mullet.
[Statement 7]: In the Mediterranean Sea, the prohibition of towed bottom gear has been found to increase the recruitment of red mullet.
[Statement 8]: A study in the Mediterranean found that a ban on towed bottom fishing gears had no effect on the abundance of bottom-dwelling fish species.
[Statement 9]: In the Indian Ocean, studies have found that fish species diversity varies between areas with different exposures to bottom trawling.
[Statement 10]: In the Indian Ocean, prohibiting beach and all other seine nets for 3–6 years was found to result in higher overall fish catch rates.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does the effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary between the North Atlantic and other regions like the Mediterranean or Indian Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A separator trawl was found in one study to separate unwanted cod from target fish species.
[Statement 2]: A larger mesh size allowed more smaller cod to escape the separator trawl.
[Statement 3]: A separator trawl fitted with a square-mesh escape panel caught less of one of two unwanted fish species.
[Statement 4]: Two of four studies found that using a topless trawl reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod.
[Statement 5]: Two of four studies found that using a topless trawl reduced discards of commercial fish species.
[Statement 6]: One study used a topless trawl in combination with another non-conventional trawl type.
[Statement 7]: A study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock and larger Atlantic cod in one of two cases.
[Statement 8]: The same study found that topless trawls did not reduce catches of smaller haddock.
[Statement 9]: A study found that discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species were reduced in topless trawls.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do separator trawls and topless trawls compare in their effectiveness at reducing unwanted fish catch?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configurations on marine fish?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Modifying fishing trap or pot configurations has been shown to have several effects on marine fish.
[Statement 2]: Sixteen of twenty studies found that modifications such as using a different trap type, increasing mesh size, or fitting an escape device reduced the unwanted catches of fish.
[Statement 3]: The reduced unwanted catches of fish included undersized, discarded, or non-commercial target species like brown trout, black sea bass, herring, and cod.
[Statement 4]: One study found that the number of unwanted species, including fish and invertebrates, was lower in modified traps.
[Statement 5]: Three other studies found that trap modifications had no effect on the unwanted catches of white croaker, non-commercial fish, or undersized Atlantic cod.
[Statement 6]: In one case, non-target haddock catches were increased by trap modifications.
[Statement 7]: Three of four studies found that traps modified with a square mesh escape window or larger mesh sizes improved the size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species.
[Statement 8]: Another study found that increasing the mesh size of a trap escape panel had no effect on the size-selectivity of panga.
[Statement 9]: One study on survival rates found that the survival of small herring that escaped from a pontoon fish trap through a size-sorting grid was similar to the survival of trap-caught herring that did not pass through a grid.
[Statement 10]: Modifications to fishing nets to prevent seal access, such as installing wire grids or steel bars, have been found to reduce damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 11]: Modifications to fishing nets to prevent seal access have resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon.

[Statement 1]: Nine studies have examined the effectiveness of attaching electropositive deterrents to fishing gear.
[Statement 2]: Studies on the effectiveness of attaching electropositive deterrents to fishing gear were conducted in the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Alaska, the South Pacific Ocean, the Tasman Sea, and in laboratory settings.
[Statement 3]: Three out of four replicated studies found that the presence of deterrent materials near bait reduced the frequency of feeding attempts by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks.
[Statement 4]: Three out of four replicated studies found that the presence of deterrent materials near bait reduced bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks.
[Statement 5]: One study found that a deterrent material did not reduce bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks.
[Statement 6]: One study on deterrent materials found that the bait consumption of commercially valuable Pacific halibut was unaffected by the deterrent materials.
[Statement 7]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that fishing gear equipped with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks, and rays compared to standard fishing gear.
[Statement 8]: Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that fishing gear equipped with electropositive deterrents caught fewer undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear.
[Statement 9]: Two replicated, controlled studies found that electropositive deterrents on fishing gear resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, sharks, and rays when compared to gear without deterrents.
[Statement 10]: A global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents on fishing gear resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, sharks, and rays when compared to gear without deterrents.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for using electropositive deterrents on fishing gear to reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?
_gemini-2-5-pro__In European waters, what does the evidence show about the effectiveness of using a square mesh codend instead of a diamond mesh codend for reducing unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from European waters on the effectiveness of using a square mesh codend instead of a diamond mesh codend for reducing unwanted catch shows varied results.
[Statement 2]: A review of 26 studies, many conducted in European waters, found that 10 of 16 studies reported that square mesh codends reduced unwanted or non-marketable catches of various fish species when compared to diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 3]: Four of the reviewed studies found no reduction in unwanted catches for certain species when using square mesh codends.
[Statement 4]: Another study found that unwanted catch was dependent on mesh size as well as mesh shape.
[Statement 5]: Six of 14 studies on size selectivity found that square mesh codends improved size selectivity for several fish species.
[Statement 6]: Five of 14 studies on size selectivity found no difference between square and diamond mesh codends.
[Statement 7]: The effect of the mesh shape on size selectivity could vary depending on the fish's body shape.
[Statement 8]: There is evidence that the short-term survival of some fish species is higher after escaping through a square mesh codend.
[Statement 9]: One study in the English Channel discovered that a trawl net with a square mesh codend and square mesh escape panels was effective in reducing the amount of discarded finfish in comparison to a diamond mesh codend without panels.
[Statement 10]: Another study in the English Channel found that a trawl with a square mesh codend caught fewer non-commercial unwanted invertebrates in one of two areas studied when compared to a diamond mesh codend.

[Statement 1]: Ceasing or prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area has shown varied effects on fish community composition and species richness.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Caribbean Sea indicated that after seven years, protected areas closed to all fishing exhibited lower total fish species richness compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 3]: A study from the Philippine Sea found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing zone of a multi-zoned protected area after 10 to 15 years, when compared with partially fished and unprotected areas.
[Statement 4]: A study in the Skagerrak found that cod survival increased within a marine protected area eight years after fishing was prohibited, compared to fished areas outside the reserve.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented benefits of ceasing all fishing in a marine protected area on fish community composition and species richness?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Rotating a diamond mesh codend by 90° improved size selection for cod, red mullet, common pandora, and other round-bodied fish species.
[Statement 2]: Rotating a diamond mesh codend by 90° did not improve size selection for plaice, annular sea bream, and other flatfish species.
[Statement 3]: One study found that a rotated diamond mesh did not improve size selectivity for cod, plaice, or flounder.
[Statement 4]: A square mesh codend improved size selectivity for silver hake, horse mackerel, European hake, axillary seabream, poor cod, greater forkbeard, and blue whiting.
[Statement 5]: A square mesh codend improved size selectivity for three out of four commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for Atlantic mackerel, long rough dab, yellowtail scad, striped seapike, rockfish, and flatfish.
[Statement 7]: The effectiveness of square mesh codends varied by fish body shape.
[Statement 8]: Square mesh codends showed improved selectivity for roundfish.
[Statement 9]: Square mesh codends did not show improved selectivity for flatfish.
[Statement 10]: An increase in mesh size can increase size selectivity for both square and diamond mesh codends.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does using a square mesh codend compare to rotating a diamond mesh codend for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the Tasman Sea, a before-and-after study found that the fish assemblage and species composition were different after prohibiting all commercial fishing in an estuary for two years.
[Statement 2]: In the South Atlantic Ocean, a site comparison study found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How do the effects on fish community composition of prohibiting all commercial fishing compare between the Tasman Sea and the South Atlantic Ocean?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What does the evidence suggest about the timeframe over which prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area leads to increased fish abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: After one to eight years of prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions, the abundance of copper rockfish, quillback rockfish, china rockfish and lingcod was similar to sites open to fishing.
[Statement 2]: After seven years of restricting all fishing except for bait fishing, there was similar total fish biomass compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 3]: After seven years of restricting all fishing except for bait fishing, there was lower total fish density compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 4]: Cod survival increased inside a marine protected area in the eight years after almost all fishing was prohibited, compared to fished areas.
[Statement 5]: An area closed to customary fishing for eight years had a higher abundance of only one of seven fish species compared to an area open to customary fishing.
[Statement 6]: Five years after prohibiting almost all fishing except restricted line fishing and bait netting, immature pigeye sharks and adult spottail sharks were detected frequently and over long time periods inside marine protected areas.

[Statement 1]: Two worldwide systematic reviews found that fisheries with catch shares had lower rates of over-exploitation compared to those without catch shares.
[Statement 2]: The two worldwide systematic reviews found a higher proportion of fisheries with catch shares met or surpassed management targets for exploitation rates.
[Statement 3]: One of the worldwide systematic reviews discovered that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to achieve management targets for biomass sustainability.
[Statement 4]: The other worldwide systematic review found no significant difference in the performance of fisheries with catch shares when compared to fleet-wide catch caps or fishing effort controls.
[Statement 5]: A before-and-after study in the Pacific Ocean indicated that after a species-specific catch share was established, the unwanted catch of halibut in a multi-species fishery was reduced.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of setting catch shares by area on marine fish populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence from global reviews on the effectiveness of catch share systems for managing fish stocks sustainably?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five studies examined the effects of long-term fishery closures on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Norwegian Sea found that after five years of closure, the weights of young salmon returning to rivers were higher.
[Statement 3]: In a study in the Norwegian Sea, older salmon weights were similar or lower after five years of closure.
[Statement 4]: A study in the Gulf of Maine found smaller but similar condition monkfish inside a closed area compared to an open one.
[Statement 5]: Two studies in the Gulf of Maine and Bismark Sea noted a higher abundance of only one of seven fish species in areas closed for six to eight years.
[Statement 6]: Two studies in the Gulf of Maine and Bismark Sea noted a lower abundance of monkfish in areas closed for six to eight years.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Bismark Sea observed that six of seven fish species in a closed area had a lower flight response distance.
[Statement 8]: A lower flight response distance made six of seven fish species in a closed area in the Bismark Sea more vulnerable to capture.
[Statement 9]: A combination of long-term closures and gear restrictions reduced unwanted cod catch.
[Statement 10]: Five studies investigated temporary fishery closures.
[Statement 11]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in spawning cod biomass compared to fished areas over nine years.
[Statement 12]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod survival compared to fished areas over nine years.
[Statement 13]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod length composition compared to fished areas over nine years.
[Statement 14]: Tagged adult cod were found to spend nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area.
[Statement 15]: Spending nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area afforded tagged adult cod increased protection.
[Statement 16]: One study in the North Sea reported that temporary closures had little effect on fishing effort for cod.
[Statement 17]: A study in the North Sea reported that real-time closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught.
[Statement 18]: One study in the Philippine Sea and Mediterranean Sea found that during a temporary closure of a grouper fishery, spear fishers' catch of other fish groups increased.
[Statement 19]: A study found that catch rates of red mullet and total catch increased after temporary closures.
[Statement 20]: A study found that catch rates for European hake did not increase after temporary closures.
[Statement 21]: A study in the Atlantic Ocean saw no change in cod catches over nine years following a temporary closure compared to fished areas.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the comparative effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the observed effects of fitting deterrents, such as lights or electropositive materials, to fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Nine studies investigated the effects of electropositive deterrents on fishing gear.
[Statement 2]: Three of four studies found that electropositive deterrents reduced feeding attempts by some shark species.
[Statement 3]: Three of four studies found that electropositive deterrents reduced bait consumption by some shark species.
[Statement 4]: Two of four studies found that fishing gear with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted fish, sharks, and rays.
[Statement 5]: Two other studies found that electropositive deterrents had no effect on the catch of unwanted sharks and rays.
[Statement 6]: A global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents had no effect on the catch of unwanted sharks and rays.
[Statement 7]: One study on visual deterrents found that gillnets with floating shark shapes attached caught fewer green turtles than unmodified nets.
[Statement 8]: Another study showed that shark-shaped deterrents had mixed effects on loggerhead turtle behaviour.
[Statement 9]: Another study showed that spherical deterrents had mixed effects on loggerhead turtle behaviour.
[Statement 10]: One study on the use of artificial lights found that shrimp trawl nets with lights caught fewer unwanted fish.
[Statement 11]: One study on the use of artificial lights found that the lights did not improve size-selectivity for certain fish species on a sorting grid.

[Statement 1]: Protecting spawning fish from capture had no effect on Atlantic cod biomass, survival, or length over nine years in one study.
[Statement 2]: Tagged cod and school sharks used closed areas designed to protect spawning fish.
[Statement 3]: A temporary closure for grouper led to increased fishing pressure on other species in one study.
[Statement 4]: Establishing temporary fishery closures showed no change in cod stock biomass, survival, or length composition in one study.
[Statement 5]: Tagged cod used a seasonally closed spawning area.
[Statement 6]: Real-time closures were found to be more effective at reducing cod catch than fixed temporary closures.
[Statement 7]: A global review found that restricting fishing in a marine protected area resulted in higher fish abundance in 10 of 11 studies.
[Statement 8]: A global review found that restricting fishing in a marine protected area resulted in larger fish in 5 of 11 studies.
[Statement 9]: A study on blackspot snapper found higher survival and larger sizes for the snapper within a marine park.
[Statement 10]: Prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area led to increased cod survival in one study.
[Statement 11]: Sharks were observed to use marine protected areas, which reduced the sharks' mortality risk.
[Statement 12]: One study found lower fish species richness in a protected area.
[Statement 13]: Two other studies found similar fish abundance for some species when comparing protected and unprotected areas.
[Statement 14]: A global review found that designating a Marine Protected Area with some fishing restrictions increased the number of lobsters and scallops.
[Statement 15]: Other studies noted increased numbers of sea cucumbers, hydrozoans, and sponges in a protected area.
[Statement 16]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of releasing fish that are carrying eggs or live young.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective spatial management actions for protecting spawning fish and their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting all fishing in a protected area in the Mediterranean Sea resulted in a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting all fishing in a protected area in the Indian Ocean resulted in a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 3]: Studies in the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean found higher fish species richness in no-take marine protected areas.
[Statement 4]: Studies in the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean found higher fish abundance in no-take marine protected areas.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found that no-take marine protected areas had similar levels of fish species richness and abundance to fished areas.
[Statement 6]: The effect of no-take marine protected areas on fish abundance can vary between species and groups in both the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean.
[Statement 7]: Studies in both the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea have found that no-take protected areas host larger fish compared to fished areas.
[Statement 8]: A study on zoned marine protected areas in the Indian Ocean found larger fish in the no-take zones compared to partially fished zones.
[Statement 9]: A study in the Indian Ocean noted that the stock biomass of reef fish was highest in enforced protected areas that were closed to all fishing.
[Statement 10]: A study in the Mediterranean Sea found a higher number of eggs from commercially targeted fish species within a non-fished reserve.
[Statement 11]: A study in the Mediterranean Sea found that commercial fish catch rates were highest closest to a no-take reserve.
[Statement 12]: One study in the Indian Ocean observed higher fish grazing rates in non-fished areas.
[Statement 13]: A study in the Indian Ocean found that most individuals of five tagged fish species stayed within a marine reserve zone closed to fishing over a nine-year period.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__How does the effectiveness of no-take marine protected areas on fish communities differ between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean?
